ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My Spanish improved a lot, especially my language production abilities.
I learned a lot about Spanish culture and film. This was the first class where it really started to seem that I was applying Spanish rather than simply learning it.
I learned how to view language learning through the lens of not only speaking, but media.
I learned a lot about speaking and writing in Spanish. I also engaged with a lot of media (films, books, articles, etc) in the Spanish language, which was interesting.
I improved my Spanish speaking and writing abilities significantly and better understood Latin american culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: I really enjoyed the variety of assignments and think it benefitted my learning greatly.  

Weaknesses: I really would have appreciated more class time/homework time devoted to grammar
This course is strong because it encourages students to use complete Spanish and engage with their peers.
I need to work on my speaking more to have easy flowing conversations but reading and writing has improved a lot.

I enjoyed the format of this class for the most part. I thought sometimes the worksheets bordered on busy-work, as the questions on them were not always interesting and seemed like they were designed to just fill up class-time. However, I thought the emphasis on implicit learning through speaking was actually very helpful as time went on. Previously, I have learned Spanish through grammar worksheets, but I actually thought I picked up the grammar better by focusing less on it and more on speaking and writing, though the learning curve was steeper.

Strengths- great professor, loved all the different materials we looked over, they were very interesting 

Weaknesses- They need grammar lessons. I get what they are trying to do by having us use new grammar in class without explicitly going over it. But we are not native speakers, we are not immersed. To be able to effectively learn grammar that way, we need way more exposure which a 50 minute class is not going to do. Just take one class period to go over this stuff, please.
Diversify the types of assignments that are being given to students and make classes more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I took this for my language requirement and definitely feel like it'll be helpful in my life.
I would recommend this because I feel that classes like these are key steps to gaining greater fluency in the Spanish language.
Yes, the teacher was helpful and the structure was beneficial to learning.
Yes, I would recommend this course. If you are looking to fill the language requirement, this is a pretty fine way to do it. Going to class four days a week though was a bit annoying.

Yes, I actually really enjoyed this course. We did a lot of projects, but everything still seemed to be focused on your use of Spanish rather than creativity, which is nice. The materials were interesting and I learned a lot about Spanish Culture.
Only if the course has to be taken for a requirement but otherwise no because the class is not engaging at all.
